headline.main: The Pill at 40: Renewed, Improved and in Its Prime

docs.abstract: Birth control pill is approaching its 40th anniversary; concerns raised in 1970's about side effects have been reduced through reformulation and screening; pill has been shown to have many health benefits beyond preventing pregnancy; tables (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The birth control pill is pushing 40, and like many another veteran of the 1960's, it never looked so good. It is the Volkswagen Bug of drugs -- a sleekly remodeled version of the 1960 prototype, housed in a box full of old associations, but completely reconfigured inside and intended for a brand-new market. Today's pills use hormone doses that are a small fraction of what they once were. While not utterly risk-free, they are far safer than the original versions and remain among the most effective forms of birth control on the market.

headline.main: Cigarette Tax Supported by Unlikely Coalition

docs.abstract: Rob Reiner, film director and Democrat, comments on his unlikely coalition with Republican Michael Huffington and conservative icon Charlton Heston in support of California initiative to raise cigarette tax by 50 cents a pack and use money for young children and antismoking programs, interview; sees tax discouraging youth smoking; tobacco industry has poured millions of dollars into fight against initiative; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A lifelong Democrat, the film director Rob Reiner does not have a lot in common politically with people like the millionaire Michael Huffington, a Republican, or the actor Charlton Heston, a conservative icon. ''We don't agree on much, that's true,'' Mr. Reiner said the other day in his office at The Culver Studios near here. ''But the one thing we do agree on is helping young children.''
